Award.AwardTitle: Reliability-based Analysis and Design Loads for Slender Cable-Supported Bridges Subjected to Cable Loss

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abrupt cable loss is a critical extreme event for cable-supported bridges, which can happen under intentional attack scenario or deterioration of cables. Slender long-span bridges may have simultaneous presence of a large number of vehicles or significant wind along with sudden breakage of cables. Most cable-loss events occur suddenly without much warning when service loads like traffic and wind may be present. Such combined extreme and service loads have not been considered in the existing cable-loss analyses. The current load resistant factor design (LRFD) specification do not consider simultaneous loading. The proposed research is to develop a reliability-based dynamic analysis method for slender long-span cable-supported bridges under combined extreme (cable breakage) and service loads such as traffic and/or wind. Analytical method development along with validation with wind tunnel testing is part of the project.

The project will pursue research in response, safety and reliability of cable supported long-span bridges in case of a sudden loss of one or more cables. The cable loss causes dynamic loads on the bridge which can have catastrophic consequences since cable-stayed bridges depend on cables as the main supporting element. A variety of scenario of cable failure and moving traffic on the bridge will be developed to encompass realistic situations. Non-linear analytical simulation will be developed for limit state situation which will be validated with scale model experiment in wind tunnel (normal moving traffic and wind are part of scenario loading). The ultimate goal of the project is to provide consistent reliability to long-span cable supported bridges under various realistic load and accident conditions. Results of the project will be disseminated through publications as well as will be made available to standard writing bodies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Long-span cable-supported bridges are backbones of modern socities, supporting major corridors and critical daily activity in the community. For thesebridges, cables are criticak strucuctural components, which are vulnerable to potential losses. The causes include corrosion, fatigue, accidental and intentional actions.

Cable loss (breakage) events can be disastrous to cable-stayed bridges because of potential risks of progressive collapse following the initial failure of stay cables. Due to the critical role of cables among all major components, cable-stayed bridges are usually required to be designed against a single-cable breakage incident. It is known that long-span bridges support a high number of vehicles every day and is also under considerable wind effects. Most existing cable breakage studies were limited to some scenario-based studies with simplified structural models, loads and simulation methodologies, without considering the dynamic interactions between the bridge, cables, vehicles and wind. This project is to systematically investigate the cable loss incidents on cable-stayed bridges and predict the dynamic performance and potential damage and failure risks of these critical infrastructures by more realistically replcating the actual scenarios.  

As a result of this project, the advanced anlytical and simulation tool to assess long-span bridge dynamic performance under combined effects of traffic and wind is developed. Further, the cable loss simulation methdology is also developed for the first time, which can be used to study complex cable loss incidents on cable-stayed bridges. Numerical examples of this project also disclose some insights that can helpd design safer, more resilient bridges subjected to future incidents.
